facts.text: Appeal from the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta Civil Appeal No. LI of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the High Court of Judicature at Calcut- ta Civil Appeal No. LI of 1949. Manohar Lal,  H.K. Mitter with him , for the appellant. C. Mitter, for the respondent. 1950. March 14.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on 1950 March 14 by FAZL ALI J.

anchor.surface_text: 1950. March 14. The judgment of the Court was deliv- ered by FAZL ALI J.---The only question to be decided in this appeal, which arises out of an execution proceeding, is whether the decree under execution is barred by limitation.

facts.text: First court held that the decree was barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The first companyrt held that the decree was number barred, but the High Court has companye to the opposite companyclusion, and the decree-holder has, after obtaining a certificate under Section 110 of the Civil Procedure Code, appealed to this Court.

facts.text: High Court held that the decree was not barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The first companyrt held that the decree was number barred, but the High Court has companye to the opposite companyclusion, and the decree-holder has, after obtaining a certificate under Section 110 of the Civil Procedure Code, appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Decree-holder obtained certificate under Section 110 CPC and appealed to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The first companyrt held that the decree was number barred, but the High Court has companye to the opposite companyclusion, and the decree-holder has, after obtaining a certificate under Section 110 of the Civil Procedure Code, appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Preliminary mortgage decree passed ex parte on 21st August 1940 in suit by appellant to enforce mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: The facts may be briefly stated as follows. On the 21st August, 1940, a preliminary mortgage decree was passed ex parte in a suit instituted by the appellant to enforce a mortgage.

facts.text: Judgment-debtor applied under Order IX rule 13 CPC on 19th September 1940 to set aside ex parte decree.

anchor.surface_text: On the 19th September, 1940, the judg- ment-debtor made an application under Order IX, rule 13, of the Civil Procedure Code for setting aside the ex parte decree, but this application was rejected on the 7th June, 1941.

facts.text: Application under Order IX rule 13 rejected on 7th June 1941.

anchor.surface_text: On the 19th September, 1940, the judg- ment-debtor made an application under Order IX, rule 13, of the Civil Procedure Code for setting aside the ex parte decree, but this application was rejected on the 7th June, 1941.

facts.text: Judgment-debtor filed application under Section 36 Bengal Money Lenders Act on 11th July 1941 to reopen preliminary decree.

anchor.surface_text: On the 11th July, 1941, the judgment-debtor filed an application under Section a6 of the Bengal Money lenders Act, for reopening the preliminary decree, but this applica- tion was dismissed for default of appearance on the 20th December, 1941.

facts.text: Application under Section 36 Bengal Money Lenders Act dismissed for default on 20th December 1941.

anchor.surface_text: On the 11th July, 1941, the judgment-debtor filed an application under Section a6 of the Bengal Money lenders Act, for reopening the preliminary decree, but this applica- tion was dismissed for default of appearance on the 20th December, 1941.

facts.text: Final mortgage decree passed in favour of appellant on 22nd December 1941.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, a final mortgage decree was passed in favour of the appellant, on the 22nd December.

facts.text: Judgment-debtor made application under Order IX rule 9 CPC for restoration of proceedings under Section 36 Money Lenders Act.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment-debtor then made an application under Order IX, rule 9, of the Civil Procedure Code for the restoration of the proceedings under Section 36 of the Money lenders Act.

facts.text: Application under Order IX rule 9 dismissed on 1st June 1942.

anchor.surface_text: The application. was however dismissed on the 1 st June, 1942, both on the ground that numbersufficient cause for the numberappearance of the applicant and his failure to take steps in the proceedings was shown and on the ground that numberpurpose would be served by reopening the preliminary decree after the final decree had been passed.

facts.text: Judgment-debtor preferred appeal to High Court from dismissal of Order IX rule 9 application.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment-debtor thereafter preferred an appeal to the High Court at Calcutta from the decision dismissing his application under Order IX, rule 9, but the appeal was dismissed for number-prosecution, on the 3rd July, 1944.

facts.text: Appeal to High Court dismissed for non-prosecution on 3rd July 1944.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment-debtor thereafter preferred an appeal to the High Court at Calcutta from the decision dismissing his application under Order IX, rule 9, but the appeal was dismissed for number-prosecution, on the 3rd July, 1944.

facts.text: Appellant filed execution application on 9th April 1945 against original judgment-debtor who had died previously.

anchor.surface_text: On the 9th April, 1945, the appellant filed an application for executing the decree against the original judgment-debtor, though he had died previously, and this application was dismissed for default on the 11th May, 1945.

facts.text: Original judgment-debtor had died before 9th April 1945.

anchor.surface_text: On the 9th April, 1945, the appellant filed an application for executing the decree against the original judgment-debtor, though he had died previously, and this application was dismissed for default on the 11th May, 1945.

facts.text: Execution application of 9th April 1945 dismissed for default on 11th May 1945.

anchor.surface_text: On the 9th April, 1945, the appellant filed an application for executing the decree against the original judgment-debtor, though he had died previously, and this application was dismissed for default on the 11th May, 1945.

facts.text: Present execution application filed on 2nd June 1945.

anchor.surface_text: On the 2nd June, 1945, the present application for execution was filed, and the question which we have to decide is whether this application is in time.

facts.text: Execution application filed more than three years after final decree.

anchor.surface_text: It is quite clear that the application for execution having been made more than three years after the date of the final decree, it must be held to be timebarred, unless, as has been companytended before us, the case falls under either clause 2 or clause 3 of article 182 of the Indian Limitation Act.

facts.text: Appellant contends case falls under clause 2 or 3 of article 182 Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is quite clear that the application for execution having been made more than three years after the date of the final decree, it must be held to be timebarred, unless, as has been companytended before us, the case falls under either clause 2 or clause 3 of article 182 of the Indian Limitation Act.

facts.text: Appellant contends application under Section 36 Money Lenders Act was application for review under clause 3 article 182.

anchor.surface_text: It is companytended that the case is companyered by clause 3,and the ground urged in support of this companytention is that the application made by the judgment-debtor for reopening the preliminary mortgage decree under Section 36 of the Money- lenders Act must be regarded as an application for review

facts.text: Court holds no substance in contention that application under Section 36 was review.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is numbersubstance in this companyten- tion. The important words in clause 3 of article 182 are 1  where there has been a review and  2  the decision passed on the review .

facts.text: Court never undertook to review the decree.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, even if it be assumed that the word review has been used in article 182 in a large sense and that the application for reopening the decree under Section 36 of the Bengal Money lenders Act was an application for review, the appellant cannot succeed, because the companyrt never undertook or purported to review the decree in question.

facts.text: Application under Section 36 for reopening preliminary decree dismissed for default.

anchor.surface_text: What actual- ly happened was that the application under Section a6 for reopening the preliminary decree  number the final decree which is the decree sought to be executed  was dismissed for default
Section 110 of the Civil Procedure Code

arguments.claim: No sufficient cause shown for non-appearance and failure to take steps; no purpose served by reopening preliminary decree after final decree passed

anchor.surface_text: The application. was however dismissed on the 1 st June, 1942, both on the ground that numbersufficient cause for the numberappearance of the applicant and his failure to take steps in the proceedings was shown and on the ground that numberpurpose would be served by reopening the preliminary decree after the final decree had been passed.

arguments.claim: Even assuming 'review' in broad sense includes Section 36 application, court never undertook or purported to review the decree

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, even if it be assumed that the word review has been used in article 182 in a large sense and that the application for reopening the decree under Section 36 of the Bengal Money lenders Act was an application for review, the appellant cannot succeed, because the companyrt never undertook or purported to review the decree in question.

arguments.claim: The Section 36 application was for reopening the preliminary decree, not the final decree under execution, and was dismissed for default

anchor.surface_text: What actual- ly happened was that the application under Section a6 for reopening the preliminary decree  number the final decree which is the decree sought to be executed  was dismissed for default

holdings.text: The execution application is time-barred because it was filed more than three years after the final decree and the case does not fall under clause 2 or clause 3 of Article 182 of the Indian Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is quite clear that the application for execution having been made more than three years after the date of the final decree, it must be held to be timebarred, unless, as has been companytended before us, the case falls under either clause 2 or clause 3 of article 182 of the Indian Limitation Act. Under these clauses, time to make the application begins to run from-- 2.  Where there has been an appeal  the date of the final decree or order of the appellate Court, or the with- drawal of the appeal, or

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 182 prescribes 3-year limitation from final decree unless exceptions in clauses 2 or 3 apply; court later holds clause 3 inapplicable and no basis shown for clause 2.

holdings.text: There is no substance in the contention that the application under Section 36 of the Bengal Money Lenders Act to reopen the preliminary decree constitutes a review under clause 3 of Article 182.

anchor.surface_text: It is companytended that the case is companyered by clause 3,and the ground urged in support of this companytention is that the application made by the judgment-debtor for reopening the preliminary mortgage decree under Section 36 of the Money- lenders Act must be regarded as an application for review and time should be held to run from the date of the final order passed in the proceedings companynected with that applica- tion. In our opinion, there is numbersubstance in this companyten- tion. The important words in clause 3 of article 182 are 1  where there has been a review and  2  the decision passed on the review .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contention rejected based on textual requirement of actual review by court and decision thereon, not mere filing of application.

holdings.text: Clause 3 of Article 182 applies only where it is shown that the court undertook to review the relevant decree or order and passed a decision on the review.

anchor.surface_text: These words show that before a case can be brought under article 182,clause 3, it must be shown firstly that the court had undertaken to review the relevant decree or order and secondly, that there has been a decision.on.the review.In the present case,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Derived from plain language of 'where there has been a review' and 'the decision passed on the review', requiring court action beyond receiving application.

holdings.text: Even assuming 'review' under Article 182 clause 3 includes a Section 36 Bengal Money Lenders Act application in a broad sense, the appellant cannot succeed as the court never undertook or purported to review the decree, the application having been dismissed for default and concerning the preliminary decree not the final decree under execution.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, even if it be assumed that the word review has been used in article 182 in a large sense and that the application for reopening the decree under Section 36 of the Bengal Money lenders Act was an application for review, the appellant cannot succeed, because the companyrt never undertook or purported to review the decree in question. What actual- ly happened was that the application under Section a6 for reopening the preliminary decree  number the final decree which is the decree sought to be executed  was dismissed for default

holdings.reasoning_summary: No court review undertaken due to dismissal for default of appearance; application targeted preliminary decree, not the executable final decree; restoration application also dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant cannot succeed, because the companyrt never undertook or purported to review the decree in question.
